title: Panel: Semantic Technologies for Big Data analaytics: Challenges and opportunities

author: David R. Karger, Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL), Massachusetts Institute of Technology, MIT

segmentation: I thought it might be fun to play the gadfly today.
So.
So this is what I want to argue about big Data.
OK.
I had hoped that I could say that well.
So let's talk about what really big data is.
We've been hearing a lot about big data from the previous panelists already talking about all these big numbers, right?
Giant amounts of data, giant amounts of money, giant amounts of opportunity.
But what is it?
Well, in general, so I should say background that I'm part of the big data research effort at MIT and also in this Intel science and Technology Center for Big Data.
So I do think about big Data.
And my sense is that big data is about data that's right at the limits of what computers can handle.
So back when I was doing information retrieval in 1994 and our our index stopped working because we had just passed the two GB limit on the file system, 2 gigabytes.

Is big Data an now something else is big data, but there's always some limit to our computers can handle, and So what big data people seem to be trying to do is applying technique is applying techniques that are really trivial on small data.
Things like regression and shortest paths, nearest neighbors, things we would think about doing.
But when you scale up the data really large.
Now it becomes a hard problem and you have to think about how to do it well, and so in general it seems that everything is sacrificed for the sake of performance.
This has tremendous potential, that's clearer, and I think several of our speakers have already iterated that.
I don't need to restate it.
But what is the semantic web angle?
Honest, I actually I take note that several of the I think several of the presentations so far have talked a lot about big data without mentioning the semantic Web, and I don't.
I don't think that's a coincidence.
Because perform because big data is all about performance.
You face constraints.
So for example nobody is going to transfer their big data right?
The 40 terabytes that are coming in from the from the whatever telescope they sit on a central server somewhere.
You don't move them around on the web, you do computation in one place.
Also, in general, if you're going to have to worry about performance, you're going to try and optimize that performance by hard coding.
Removing any unneeded generality from the system, and this is exactly counter to the semantic web, which works very hard to build very general tools.
So for example, we're just listening to Ari talking about how at the moment at least, SQL databases with specific tables will outperform triplestores.
And perhaps that will change in the future, but it seems to be true now.
Similarly, I think you'll find that specialized machine learning techniques for particular domains will outperform general machine learning techniques.
An I think we're going to see again these sort of hard coded systems because analysts who are worried most about performance will trade ease of use for performance.
I'm looking at it another way.
If we think about big data versus notion of schemas.
So as I argued this morning, I think the big strength of the semantic web is it's mutable schemas.
So there's a big focus on the rich on working with data that has very rich schematic structure.
But if you think about it in big Data, or at least every big data set that I've seen, the ratio of schemata data goes to 0, right?

It's all data and then a tiny amount of schema, and so arbitrarily difficult schema work like alignment of different schemas or understanding what the different columns mean become negligible compared to the amount of effort that you're going to be investing in the data processing.
So for example, you can let people do it an it's a negligible part of the overall.
Workflow, so it seems to me that the semantic web be addressing the unimportant piece of these bigger data.

I also want to argue for the benefits of unity and this actually came out, I think in always talk as well, given the critical role that databases are going to play in big data work, I think the tackling big data outside their community will fragment the work and make it less effective, reduce communication.

So I would argue for publishing big data, work in SIGMOD and VLDB Similarly if you're going to be thinking about machine learning, information extraction, text mining that should be published in national in KDD, because that's where.
Expertise is or where the center of the expertise is.
So.
There's some caveats.

Maybe there is a semantic web big data problem, but for it to really be a semantic web big data problem, I think it would have to involve massive numbers of schemas, and I don't think that we see that in any big data problem that people are tackling right now.
Right now, people have one schema that is their companies data or their company.
7 schemas.
Millions of schemas.
Maybe that's a semantic web big data problem.
So for example, if we wanted to redo Google on the semantic web and had to deal with every scheme in the world at once, maybe that would be a semantic web big data problem.
Thank you.
